intro: Glandulicereus montanus, commonly known as the night blooming cereus, is a flowering plant native to Central and South America. It belongs to the Cactaceae family and is characterized by its spiny, columnar stems and nocturnal blooming habit. The plant produces large, showy white flowers that open at night, often with a sweet fragrance. Its flowers are typically short-lived, lasting only a few hours, and it is adapted to arid environments with minimal water requirements. Glandulicereus montanus is often cultivated for its ornamental value and unique blooming behavior.
